For anyone wanting to do this sort of thing, please make sure to use valves rated for cryogenic service. What can happen (in ball valves, for example, but something similar can happen with certain other types of valves as well): liquid flows through the ball, then the ball is closed. The closed volume inside the ball then has a bunch of liquid that wants to boil off as it warms up, creating a very high pressure.

I always laugh a bit when one 's speaking about "high pressure materials" and then takes 316 as one. 3Kpsi is definitely a high pressure, but 316 steel grade is just as good as 321 or 304; main reason to use them is that they are pretty ductile and don't become brittle when exposed to low temperatures unlike carbon (or martensitic stainless) steel or many kinds of plastic. With sufficient thickness, aluminum or brass parts shall work just as good and they are way more available at least in some areas.

Also It's important to note that a supercritical fluid is not just "a mixture of liquid and gas due to both having the same density."
It's its own state. E.g. there are things that can be dissolved in certain supercritical fluids that can't be dissolved in the liquid (or gas, but that's a given) state, and vice versa.

So, the term for what happened with the colour change the second time is something called "critical opalescence", which happens at certain second order phase transitions - the average size of density fluctuations in the liquid/gas reaches the order of the size of optical light wavelengths, and causes diffraction.  This accounts for both the "cloudiness" and the colour change - I remember being shown a video of this exact orange colour during my Physics lectures.

When installing any kind of threaded fitting you can use Teflon tape and Teflon paste together for a superior seal. It's also a good habit to test your work with an air compressor and soapy water before putting it into service. I realize that a compressor capable of that kind of pressure will set you back a bit if you buy it brand new but a well maintained used unit would be a reasonable option. Especially if you can use that compressor for other experiments. When depressurizing the chamber slowly you want to use a gate valve like one would have on a outside water spigot. It gives you greater controll and will also last longer. For better temperature control you can get some heat tape/trace from a hardware store and then insulate the chamber for even heating. You could then keep everything stationary which may help prevent cracking in the future. Perhaps you could find a method to make this insulator more pliable, wouldn't that be something?

My interest in your video is supercritical materials, and their relation to the Pre-Flood Earth.

Yes, I said it.

You might check out Dr. Walt Brown, PhD. in Mechanical Engineering from MIT and his book 'In the Beginning - Compelling Evidence for Genesis and the Flood'. Dr. Brown goes into some detail about supercritical water, and how the ancient Earth most likely contained a vast layer of subterranean salty waters in its original, pristine state.

The waters were 10 to 20 miles down and under the entire, contiguous, crust of the Earth at the time. Remnants of these vast fountains of the deep still remain under China, Tibet, and all the mountain ranges, as he predicted. The remainder of these waters now reside in the salty oceans of the earth.

What happens when a supercritical source of that magnitude and potential energy is released all at once (in one day), as the Bible says?

Supercritical materials were most likely also components of the original atmosphere, in the form of layers of metallic hydrogen and liquid (or solid oxygen) suspended in magnetic layers, when the internal magnetic field of the Earth was much stronger, and the firmament itself was perhaps a layered system of stable aerogels, before it all came crashing down as rain.

Ok. So to do more at once:
Add another section of straight pipe at the bottom of the 4-way. Make a little rack that lets you stack a few gels on top of one another (like a commercial baker's rack) and load from the bottom. Have the top of this race have some wires with a half circle loop that catches on a small wire frame inside, such that you can lift it up from the bottom and then rotate it 45 degrees and lower it to set the hooks on the rack into the catches in the frame. It should hold itself down enough to handle the turbulence of all the fluid moving around without being terribly complicated to make or to engage the catch for loading (though it obviously would need to be kept upright and not shaken like crazy).

You could then either have this frame hanging out of the bottom of the 4-way and then screw on the longer bottom section with endcap already fastened, or feed it up through the long segment and just attach the endcap/ bottom valve to seal. I kind of feel like removing the whole pipe with endcap might be easier, though, since it would probably be better for have all the valve stuff set and not messed with than trying to screw that end bit on without fucking it up when slotting the socket wrench over it.

Then you can fill with methanol through the air bleeder valve or the CO2 valve, if the CO2 wouldn't cause freezing problems with the methanol in the valve (or add a 3rd valve if you want the extra bit of complexity). So screwing on the bottom pipe/ endcap would have to be done fairly quickly to make sure you don't dry the gels, but I think it can be done and would really only add the extra cost of that one straight pipe segment and the bits of wire to make that frame (which, TBH, could probably be made mostly out of plain old bailing wire or coat hangers, if you really wanted to cheap out.). I also think that once you have the pipes sealed even incompletely while you crank it down really tight, the methanol evaporation is going to slow considerably, giving you more breathing room. I live at high altitude, though, so maybe I'm overestimating the evaporation rate of... everything.

For the container for the water bath, I would suggest just using a trash can, honestly. Dirt cheap and deep. Maybe not the best, visually, but if you really wanted you could silicone in a clear acrylic window to the side. But all the action is through the pressure chamber windows, anyways, so IDK if being able to see the wonderful sight of "pipes in a bucket" really matters all that much.

Also, tiny mirror in the chamber to see the gels. You could probably even take one of those fish-eye mirrors for sticking onto your rear view mirror and cut a section in the middle out and get a nice wide angle view in the chamber. Dirt cheap at any auto parts store. Though IDK if the materials would hold up under those conditions. Even a piece of polished stainless stuck in there would be better than nothing. I'm sure you can find someone who will sell you a 1-inch square of any metal you want that's been polished to a mirror finish in any shape you want. Find a machining or metalworking YouTuber and collab for it, if companies don't want to do such a small job. Or do it yourself. Most of the mirror polishing process just requires a lot of patience. Or maybe a cheap hobby mirror would do, IDK. I just don't know if a thin sheet of mirrored glass will hold up in those conditions, and I would hate if your otherwise perfect aerogel run got ruined because a glass mirror exploded from the temperature changes and pressure or something and peppered your aerogel and valves with shards of glass.

Sorry for the novel, I've just been fascinated with aerogel since I was pretty young, and seeing this has me very tempted to just run out and blow my savings on the kit to do this. If I could think of a way to make some money back doing it, my bank would already be furious with me.

One tip for opening valves precisely: try to add leverage. Use a ratchet or some other long bar to turn the valve. It's a lot easier to move a 12 inch bar by 1 degree than it is a 2 inch valve handle. You do want a tight fit, but even then so long as you keep it locked against the surface that you're pressing on with that leverage, it should give you very fine control over how open that valve is.

Edit: oh, he figured that out on the second run. Still, though, he mentioned it as an aside, but it's a super, super, super useful thing to know when trying to get fine control like this, and it's not necessarily an intuitive thing. I think it's natural to associate more leverage with more brute force, and not so much with finer control. But, the longer the lever, the more fine you can get. Though, I wouldn't leave it hanging off of the valve, for fear of bending something out of shape or accidentally bumping it.

Best way is to use a semipermanent release agent (I suggest frekote NC-770 from Henkel-loctite) on the molds, you can apply it with an atomiser or a special rag. Apply it also to the glass bottom and fill the mold till the surface tension is over the edges but avoiding spillage. After that use an acetate film (½mil) and place it on top, the gel will seam to spill but the surface tension will suck down the acetate and will create a sealed enclosure with the mood. That will also avoid air being in contact with the gel. You can place the glass container to cover the whole mild like you did in the video and better even if you pre-heat it.
So it's 99% air and 1% sold

I don't know if you'll ever read this, but if I could make a suggestion: it's a good idea to add some kind of thread sealant paste along with your teflon tape when working with metallic pipe fittings. The sharp threading on these fittings tends to completely shred teflon tape when dry, defeating the purpose in a pressurized system. An added bonus of using paste is that any tiny gaps left behind are filled in, so you're less likely to have leaks.

PTFE tape is always applied opposite of the direction the threads tighten. If it tightens clockwise, then when you're looking down at it from the top apply it clockwise, and it will go on correctly. It sounds counter intuitive, but this way is easy to remember and it will be counter-clockwise to thread tightening when its installed. Its a matter of the perspective you're looking at it when applying compared to perspective when you're tightening, but there is one way to apply it and a lot of people mess it up. I still have to think twice before every time I use it. Looks like it went on properly in the video though, so kudos.

Also, a good rule of thumb is to give it a wrap or two extra, somewhere around 5-7 wraps, to account for the tape mashing into the thread pitch of your fittings, you want enough to mash into both sets of threads and fill any air gaps. This helps to form a good seal and makes up for the part tolerances from machining. Then when tightening go probably a full turn at least from where its snug. In this application it might be good to find out if you need to torque it to a certain setting since you're dealing with significant pressures. Shouldn't have any leaks but its always good practice to leak test any time you newly install or adjust. If it goes to crap and shreds while fitting together, then peel it, re-apply, and re-tighten to specification. Teflon tape has great temperature and pressure ratings (-240 C to 260 C @ 10,000 PSI). It can tolerate it as long as you apply enough and apply it properly.

If you do any home plumbing I'd recommend the same way if you're using iron/steel fittings or piping. Or go old school with copper, sweat the pipe with flux, and solder the fittings in place for the best plumbing results, just don't use copper in this scenario. Burst pressures are way lower with copper around 2900 PSI (for annealed copper).

Also, capillary is pronounced like "kap-ill-air-E". Never until today have I heard anyone pronounce it where it about sounds similar to caterpillar

Last note: Props on a good ball valve, exactly what you want for any application where you need an easy way to shut something off. Its a lot better and safer than any kind of valve (like a wheel, or T-handle) that screws in to shut off inflow.

@NileRed You wanted to have just your workpiece, methanol and CO2 in your chamber but you took no steps to remove residual air. That is why pressure was higher than you expected for a given temperature. In a/c systems if there are non condensibles in the system (think air) then head pressure is too high. You could have purged out air with excess CO2. A/C techs remove air with a vacuum pump but that would not have been suitable for your project.

Try using gas displacement to keep the pressure up.while removing the CO2.
Also, an internal heater in the chamber.
Automatic pressure relief at 1100 PSI.The reason to use supercritical CO2 is to remove
the methanol from the gel, nothing else. When the pressure goes down, the CO2 goes
gas, but this damages as gas creates the inverse of the methanol, instead of forces being applied
inward by the fluid tension, it will create outward tension.
And automatic pressure relief, will prevent this as it will keep the pressure stable as the CO2 gets vented.
When the pressure stays up and the CO2 gets removed, and replaced by another gas to keep the pessure up,
it will not add tension insde the gel.
The trick is changing the CO2 that's inside the gel with regular atmo that's just gas in room conditions.
Basically, it doesn't have to be regular air as it comes out of the chamber, just any gass that allows for pressurization,
while no going liquid at 1100 PSI.

Note: The color change is because of refractional difference, where supercritical CO2 and non-critical CO2 mix,
with each of those having different mechnical properties, including light refraction indices. there's also a very tiny bit of methanol dissolved, which adds further refraction differences. 3 substances mixed, with each different refraction indices
will almost surely create a color change.

some suggestions I can recommend; by no means am I an aerogel expert. For bubbles in the gel I would suggest using something that can induce a frequency to the mold/table that shake the fluid gently so that bubbles rise, or just hit the table repeatedly; however the former is a bit more elegant. For molding you can still use a syringe, just create your own square or hexagonal cylinder with the proper plunger; removes the need to use wax. For heating, you could use a taller and thinner column so less water is needed to be heated. Lastly, for the transition from water to methanol, raise the aerogel holder a bit so that water can accumulate at the bottom while methanol stays at the top; since water is more dense than methanol. Methanol is soluble one water, but if there’s enough methanol then the water should be over saturated and no longer be able to both mix; just don’t increase temp or agitate the solution.

But when I got put on testosterone injections it actually made my symptoms worse. When I saw a new doctor I was switched to the testosterone gel pretty much all my problems were solved.

It took about 6 months for the gynecomastia to start reversing and since I wasn't working out the first 6 months I didn't have the results that I could have had. BUT, Now that I have been working out for a few months, got a psych medication change, switched to AndroGel instead of testosterone cypionate injections and started eating healthier - my symptoms of gynecomastia/fatty - or non muscular - chest and a sort of odd body type for a 27 year old male has gone away almost entirely.

So anyways, what I am getting at is, talking to your Dr about receiving some lab/ blood work done to see if you have low testosterone or some other hormonal imbalance and also checking the symptoms of any medications that you're possiblity prescribed for gynecomastia or hormone imbalance then seeing if you can switch to something different or getting off of the medications altogether is something I would recommend talking to your doctor about.

It could be life-changing. Suggestion for making better visibility of aerogel formation: Instead of putting the gel lower in the chamber and filling that big area with a bunch of methanol to protect the gel, build a flat platform across the middle of the chamber and put a tiny petri dish filled with both the methanol and your gel onto the platform. It might make your process work less well, hard to say... but you would be able to get good video of the entire process. The only problem is draining the liquid methanol. Either don't worry about it and rely on solubilizing it in the CO2 before draining, or maybe add some form of wick to the side to draw the methanol out? Is there something that is soluble in CO2 but not methanol? You could build a plug out of that to drain the methanol from the petri dish once it is immersed in CO2.

Anyway, the point would be to protect the gel in a methanol tank while still keeping it at eye level.

If it works, it would also facilitate making multiple gels at the same time.

Anyway, all the work that went into this is appreciated. It was amazing to see the process from "wouldn't it be cool if?" all the way through too a hunk of pristine aerogel sitting on your bench.

I love all the details you added about the process you went through. When I used to work in a lab and I would try to recreate the methods from something I saw in a paper, they would always leave out a bunch of critical details. "Oh! You have to solubilize in DMSO before dissolving in oil!" (that one was particularly painful.... I wasted a bunch of very expensive hand-crafted retinoic acid derivative while inventing new curse words because of the drug that would not go into solution like the paper said it would.)

About the gel process: is it possible that there were some other chemical reactions at work between the Methanol and the CO2? I'm a firefighter, and that orange color made me think immediately of the color we see when inside a fire and there's superheated CO in the room(we duck and leave when we see that, because it's seconds before flash-over or explosion). Since the methanol is a combustible, and you're working at higher pressures, I think you could have similar processes at lower temperatures... It's just a wild thought, though, but maybe an option that you hadn't considered yet.

About the color of the aerogel, I think its Rayleigh scattering effect. Rayleigh scattering results from the electric polarizability of the particles. The oscillating electric field of a light wave acts on the charges within a particle, causing them to move at the same frequency. The particle, therefore, becomes a small radiating dipole whose radiation we see as scattered light. The particles may be individual atoms or molecules; it can occur when light travels through transparent solids and liquids, but is most prominently seen in gases.

Great video.  It would've been really cool to see the aerogel in the chamber.  Instead of the pizza thingy to hold the aerogel in the CO2 chamber a simple bridge that spanned the gap would've been easier to insert and remove, but also allow the camera to see it.  Another improvement might be to drill many small holes in the bottom to allow as much exposure to the aerogel as possible.  [edit] I would imagine making a multi-tier bridge would be very simple as well.  It will be fun to see what you come up with if you ever revisit this subject.

Facts: This stuff can literally be made lighter than air and goes into NASA spacecrafts as an insulator -- but perhaps more importantly, they use it to collect microscopic particles in space and to test lasers (at the National Ignition Facility) because it is such a good insulator that even a high-powered laser will only really affect the sample wherever it hits, and not cause cascading burns and screw up measurements

This was a great attempt at making perfect Aerogel. Have you considered, that the pigment in the Teflon tape (yellowish/orange) was being drawn out by the methanol and that the second attempt at the drying process, while  being more successful. pushed the pigment into the Aerogel by the higher pressure from the super critical state and continuously stable temperature. The fractures caused by capillary action is hasten by a multitude bubbles. if you were to take a time lapsed video through a  microscope to the Aerogel You will see that the fractures lead from one bubble to the next, almost like connect the dots. Plus, the bubbles will increase in size when taken from a controlled high pressure atmosphere.( not unlike the bends or decompression).  To get bubble free ice for Ice carvers. Ice makers put a vibrating source in or on the ice tank while water is freezing( hence the bumping of the table. The bubbles are keeping the silica molecules from lining.up in a crystalline structure, making the Aerogel blocks a bit more opaque on the corners and edges than a manufactured one. That being said, i totally enjoyed this video! Keep them coming and congrats on your new assistant videographer......

I am retired now, but I used to work for an independent test lab in California. Back when various aerospace companies were developing uses for Aerogel  I was tasked with figuring a way of measuring strength properties on Aerogel disks. These disks were lab samples representing various manufacturing  processes. If you have never handled Aerogel the best way I can describe it is "Will-o'-the-Wisp". It is like holding air in your hand. Measuring compression strength was fairly easy. Squeeze it between two flat plates and measure the force. Now we get to tensile strength. How do you pull on air and measure the force it takes before it breaks apart? If anyone is facing a similar situation  let me know and I can describe my solution.   BTW those vids and pics that show people picking up red hot Aerogel is correct. It IS red hot but it has insignificant thermal mass to do heat damage to flesh.

This video shows a man with incredible persistence, intelligence and a solid knowledge of Chemistry.  My guess as to the source of the yellow color: oil in the CO2.  I have used those CO2 tanks to make dry ice pellets.  If the pellets are put in a beaker and allowed to sublimate, a yellow residue of oil remains in the bottom.  I would suggest putting an oil absorbing filter in the line from the CO2 tank.  Also, for the water bath, simple using a deeper tank would alleviate the need to use aluminum foil insulation.  Some of the in-bath heaters from scientific supply companies are programmable as well.  That would help with all the baby sitting of the rig.  I have done 20 years of molecular biology research but I find these Chemistry and Physics videos enchanting.  Ted

Far too many comment to do in one sitting.  I hope you came up with an idea to do many.  High pressure pipe may have an ID that will be too small for your parts.  But that is the simplest way to increase the volume.  You can make a metal set of trays  a zig zag bent piece of metal is one approach.  Easier would be wire three sides with two space ~ 110 deg and the other between the bigger angle.  Then crimp the wire at each plate.   Then load the trays as you lower the stack into the pipe containing the liquid.   may need to add pipe to the get more volume for the CO2  The stack can be modified because you get more room above the pipe.  Can add the liquid from the drain valve for the liquid.  So one can be visible in the window.    The chamber for heating with the cooker will have to tall.  but the heater should work better.    Insulation used for cooling to -55 is the fiberglass stuff sell at the big box store for covering ducts.  It should be good for the high temperature also.  It has foil on the outside.

About the orange light at the super critical point. When i was a kid in Alabama during one summer we went through a time when during the late after noon to evening shift we would hit a point were being outside everything turned orange without sunlight actually falling on something. It was diffused and looked as though we had colored glasses on. The events would only last a few minutes. We had a local genius student who was like the rest of us kids (and some adults) became fascinated by it and did a science fair project on it.  He built a chamber much like you have here and the look your phone got through the lens was very very similar if not the same (per my memory from 30 years ago lol) of the view he had at the example portion. Apparently the summer heat and weather we had had that summer caused the phenomenon to repeat itself multiple times but it came down to heat and light refraction in the CO2 at a certain temperature. I wish for the life of me i could remember the terms but i recall it was basically an in between state during a thermic reaction. The only reason I remember even that much of the experiment is I too found those afternoons magical and inspiring in my own way in and it made me want to study light. Eventually spuring me to study photography and lighting and becoming a lighting director for theater in and out of college.  Just wanted to help a bit if I could answer a question in your experiment since you took the extra effort to explain it all in truly amazing detail. Thank you and keep it up!

One idea to help make your chamber have better visibility is to change the rack that holds your aerogel. Going with the 'pizza spatula' idea, don't make the platform of this tool as deep, use a more shallow dip. Another idea to improve on this is don't use the one tab to hang the platform, instead use two to hang on both sides of the cross section. For increasing the quantity in the chamber, keep the depth of the platform that you have for the bottom rack. Make a flat version that'll sit on top of that, another two in this configuration but inverted to fit in the top of the chamber, then it'd be a matter of stacking platforms between the two. One suggestion I'd make to keep the top from falling is to use either a magnet (either an external strip upon the rack itself, or embedded into the rack) or some adhesive that is strong enough to hold it there but weak enough to be removable.

Just a few things I must say:
1. The footage from the camera taped to the chamber is oddly beautiful, and kinda looks like shots of an empty Blade Runner 2049 set, or the bridge of some sort of alien ship from a Stanley Kubrick film.
2. If you end up doing this again you could try making a dedicated heater for the chamber: I.e. Wrapping a flexible heater pad (either a flexible resistive heater film, or even just a small plug in heated blanket), and adding a cheap programmable PID controller to precisely control the temperature and timing.
2b. You also might be able to use a 3d printer heater cartridge and thermocouple inside the chamber for much more precise temperature control of the CO2. Granted you should probably ask an expert about modifying a pressure chamber before you do anything like that.
3. As an avid tinkerer I feel I must say that you should probably just leave the chamber in the vise the whole time instead of moving it back and forth. Though, I'm probably more prone to dropping expensive things than you are.
4. What would happen if you added other components to your gel mixture? Like, ultra fine metal powder, or colourants? Maybe glow in the dark or uv reactive pigments? Could you make aerogel with different properties or colours? Or is the recipe too fragile? I only ask as my parents won't let me do science in the basement anymore so I can't try this myself.
5. Keep doing amazing stuff like this, Nile. Channels like yours never cease to inspire and amaze me. I learn something new and fascinating every time you upload something new.

@NileRed Just a thought for an alternative heating source for future aerogel projects. I'm not sure how confident you are with a soldering iron but you could easily wire up some copper heating elements and attach them to the chamber assuming the silicone tape can keep the heat away from the valves.

That sort of thing isn't the most accurate in something like a hot plate because you have a bunch of places where you lose heat. Because the contact will be direct with the chamber if you then insulate the elements with something with a large surface area like say graphite, activated carbon etc, (or aerogel xD though the mechanics of that might be tough lol) you should be able to at least have the same if not better consistency than with water.

That would be a set and forget way to process the aerogel which, after some initial testing, should hopefully require a lot less babysitting.

The aerogel appearing yellow is perfectly normal. Most silica aerogels are bluish in colour as a result of an effect called Rayleigh scattering, which is the same effect that makes the sky look blue. When you look at the light that's been transmitted directly through the aerogel it appears yellow (blue's complementary colour), because the blue light is scattered into all directions, hence there is less blue light reaching your eyes. You can see this very nicely at around 38:40 when you turn the aerogel and then when you put it on a piece of paper.

Also for all those out there that want to do this, the tape is not what makes the actual seal. All of those fittings are slightly tapered. It is actually a compression seal by the threaded parts turning in so far that both pieces of the fitting coming so close together that as you keep tightening the threads it eventually is smashed together until it is so tight that it makes a compression seal. The tape is Mainly a lubricant so that the pieces can come apart again, and adds a Small amount of sealing. There is no way to make all those fittings tight enough while the whole thing was hanging on that thin mount.

Well, 1st time watcher here, and new subscriber (this video earned it). Fascinating video, loved the extent you went to detailing your methodology. The only issue I have with videos like this, is I then almost want to write a full peer review!


I have some questions/observations about various parts of the video, but I'll just limit to some observations about that discolouration with your final product:
You hypothesize two possible causes (recipe or time-delay), but I can't really agree with either here, based on what's visible in the video.


Now, I have to make a few assumptions here:
1. The discolouration was visible in the "Hexagon" batch, but not the "Square" batch. (Appears this way in the video, but may not be the case)
2. Both batches were made using the same recipe, at roughly the same time (using the same base ingredient bottles, with short enough gap between to rule out e.g. a contaminent entering the now unsealed bottles).
3. Both batches were stored together, as the video appears to suggest.
4. You mean the long delay was between making the gels, and doing the "drying" step, not between doing the "drying" step of the two batches.


Now:
* Recipe can be ruled out based on 1 and 2. If both used the same recipe, then they should both be effected by the discolouration.


* Time-Delay, (which to me would be looking at contamination over time, e.g. atmospheric mixing, or perhaps breakdown of materials, either of the gel, or maybe the container?) should be ruled out by 1 and 3, but does require 4 as well. (If not 4, then sure it's ruled back in as a possible cause.) Again, if they are stored together, then whatever "age" factors there are should be effecting them equally, causing equal discolouration in both batches.


Instead I put forward the following:
The discolouration seems to be a contaminant of some sort, either impregnated within the silica itself, or left behind at some point later in the process (but only visible in the final product). Possible phases where the contamination could have occured would then be:
1. Mixing of the batch.
2. Pouring into the (different) mould.

3. During the Drying Process.
I'm ruling out post solidification of the gel (and pre-drying), as if the contaminant is within the liquid methanol, and not in some way bonded with the gel, it should then have mixed with both when they were put in the shared methanol bath, especially if they are stored for as long as you suggest.


For the remainder: (3 is my personal favourite)
1. Perhaps some other compound got mixed into what became the solid part of the gel in minute quantities? Possibly a residue in the beaker or pipette?
2. A different moulding tray was used here. I'm assuming they were made of the same material, so ruling out the material itself, but these things can often have residue from the machining process on them when first purchased, perhaps didn't get completely cleaned off one?
3. If a contaminant were in the chamber, or were to enter the chamber during the drying process, perhaps it bonded to the structure then? An aerosol of some sort could have entered the chamber and lodged on the inner walls, or just been present in the air inside?
This last part (along with everything else, I guess) is pure speculation: I'm not hugely experienced with Teflon tape, besides replacing a few pipe fittings at home, but I do know that the teflon tape tends to break apart somewhat when you screw and unscrew the fitting. I also know that teflon can break down, and into micrometer and nanometer sized particles. Finally, that teflon tape you were using (the "much thicker orange one") was coloured. I'm colourblind, but I'd personally call that more of a "cream"? Perhaps tiny particles that get stuck within the structure could cause that discolouration? It's hard to be sure from a few seconds from footage, but the discolouration seems to be stronger near the edges than at the core, which I guess would support the late addition of contaminant, especially one that might struggle to penetrate the similarly sized pores?
Is the discolouration weaker on the face that sat on the solid base?



Longer observations than I intended, but hopefully they help, or spark discussion?

Edit: The reason you couldn't see the aero gel in the chamber is because you backlit the gel from the other side effectively silhouetting it and there is nothing inside the tank to scatter the light. You need the light coming from the same side as the lens but you would aslo still need to have the lens right against the glass to stop the reflection from the ringlight/ studio light reflcting back into the lens. A laowa probe lens would have been great for this as it is waterproof and macro with its own light source. I don't know if they make them for Panasonic G cameras though.

To deal with the bubbles early on, abscond with your girlfriend's (boyfriend? whatever turns you on...) favorite vibrator. Turn it on, obviously, and place it on the table near the curing gels. It will only need a minute or two usually; less if you're into weapons-grade Hitachi Magic Wands. Of course, you'll need the surface to cooperate, so some super sturdy workbench may not transfer the vibration enough. It really does not take too much vibration to get excellent results tho. Be courteous, thoroughly clean, obviously, and replace the batteries & return the vibrator where you found it. It helps to make a mental note and/or picture to aid in dispelling any suspicion that the magical little device may have been used for some pseudo-nefarious purposes. I am glad to see a safety valve on the setup, but I would like to see a better way of holding the chamber without a vice. A vice can exert a lot of force. Also, ventilation is good in a room full of C02. Perhaps, a hose could be added to vent the Co2 outside.

Drilling small holes in the bottom of your pizza paddle, may ensure even the C02 replacement. These should be deburred, or the bottom of the tray should be sanded so it won't damage the gels. I like your paddle idea, and perhaps the center could even be a fine stainless mesh. I thought I saw a spot when you lifted the gel, which might be alcohol.

Perhaps the cell could be wrapped with rope-like resistance heaters, like the silicone covered ones. An controller could be made using a Arduino, and some MOSFETS, like are used in most 3D printers. I would want to place an additional NTC thermistor, a multimeter temp probe, so you can see the temperature on a 2nd piece of equipment, for safety. The heater would need to stay away from the flanges. If you had a 5-way connector instead of the 4-way, to make the chamber from, a light could be added in the top.

Issues: Petroleum based wax. Plastic Mold. Heating method.

Fix: Use a non-petrol based wax(carnauba wax would be a good option if you're set on wax), use a ceramic mold and the hardest part, use FeCrAl to heat your chamber. FeCrAl (Kanthal) can be formed into a mesh that can evenly distribute heat across your rig.

Aerogel doesn’t look rigid, or brittle. It appears to be a rubber-like substance. When you find out it’s made out of silica, that’s when you realize it’s rigid. It’s brittle because of the amount of air that’s in a network of silica, which isn’t structurally sound. At a glance, most aerogels actually look the same. They are, in a way, because they’re mostly air. The substance is so thin, that you can’t even see the color of it. It’s similar to a meringue cookie, which is basically nothing until puffed, and also very brittle.

Nile: The aerogel looks blue/orange due to Rayleigh scattering.
Rayligh scattering is also the explanation for the blue haze and the orange light in the chamber. When the particles are less than 1/10th of a micron, they scatter blue light more than the other wavelengths. Therefore it looks blue when the light comes from the side. But when you shine light through it, it looks orange.
I'd love to see you shine white light through the aerogel - I'm certain the light which comes through will be orange.
On your second video you can see a flash of blue haze (particles less than 1/10th of a micron) which quickly turns into 'white clouds' (particles larger than 0.5 microns) which are in the Mie scattering domain.
Once you understand what's happening, it's breathtakingly beautiful! It's like a bit of sky in a jar.

NEVER vent large amounts of CO2 indoors. You displaced like half the O2 in the room. You should have used a heating mantel to slowly heat the chamber. Using a heat gun not only creates hot spots but it can cause your pipe fittings to get hot spots and expand unevenly and also make it expand enough to blow out your fittings. Glad to see you used the water chamber later on but then you lift the pressure vessel from the top. That could easily have torn your arm off if the threads failed to hold.

You could try heating/dying it in a pressurized container or under vacuum so that the higher/lower pressure keeps it from cracking. You also overspent on your supercritical drying chamber by A TON. McMaster is the most expensive option for buying these things and the same with Sigma Aldrich (Literally 100+ times as expensive as other sources in some cases). AliExpress would have cost less than 1/10th but also by using different fittings you can save a ton of money as well. I have built a super critical butane chamber for under $20 that could also have been used for CO2 though.

Nice work, I made these gells based on alox particles. Process was more or less the same, but the extraction was done quicker in a cascade setup, in which the initial liquid CO2 was poored in a small basket, with a limited capacity, thus running over and getting rid of the acetone (in my case). Mine were intentional less blue due to the smaller pore size, but still somewhat blueish due to the Rayleigh scattering. I'm familiar with the pain of cracking gells, but the feeling is not really different from the experience of doing a PhD and working on stuff that doesn't work at the first attempt.

If I'm not mistaken, the gels (and potentially the blue supercritical CO2 haze) are blue reflectively and yellow transmissively. That's probably why your gel looks yellow on a white background, it scatters the blue light and transmits the yellow. If you get a piece of commercial aerogel and look at a light through it, it will look yellow, but if you just look at a piece of aerogel on a dark background the reflected light is blue.

A tip on using teflon tape: "Use more tape" is probably exactly the opposite of what you needed. PTFE tape isn't like a putty that just get's squeezed out of the way if there's too much. Putting on more can be detrimental to the strength of the joint. Importantly you should leave the first few threads uncovered so that you have more threads engaged before the PTFE tape starts binding up the threads. With the way you did it now you have very little thread engaged and thus lose a lot of strength in the joint. Then have one or two layers on the next few threads get a seal deeper in the engaged thread. Build up to 3 or 4 layers (at most) near the head of the plug/nut/joint/thingamajig. Always wrap with the direction of tightening, so that the tape gets pulled tighter when you tighten the joint (though you probably already know that). I got perfect joints like that in hydraulic (and later vacuum in a different job) systems like that every time.

I have a question Nile:
Although the Aerogel seems quite brittle it does seem to show at least some degree of resistance to compression.
Now, since it is essentially a "sponge" putting it in a vacuum chamber would leave you with an empty Silica frame. If you were then able to somehow cover it with a thin, hardening polymer coating (while still under a vacuum) you'd be left with a solid object whose density might be just a bit lower than air - essentially a "solid balloon" whose volume is prevented from collapsing due to air pressure by the Silica frame. Of course this would be easier to make the larger you make it since the surface/volume ratio quickly rises in your favor when increasing the size. And my gut feeling tells me the compressive strength probably also rises with size, although I'm not sure, to be honest.
Either way, if you were to find a way to apply a coating under a vacuum you might be able to create a floating or at least neutrally buoyant solid object.
I'd love to hear your thoughts on this and why it probably wouldn't work!

Either way, keep up the great work, I love your videos!
Best regards

EDIT: Perhaps no need to spray something on; putting it into a condom or part of a latex glove and simply sealing it once under a vacuum might do the trick.

Something you can do is use a WiFi controlled sous vide cooker then use electronic valves and electronic temperature and pressure guages. You can easily add a microcontroller like a raspberry pi or Arduino with WiFi shield to then control the 3 valves and the temperature.


Obviously this will add some cost and complexity to the setup and you will still have to manually start the process and take it out but you then wouldn't have to control the temperature yourself or baby it and make sure the pressure doesn't get to high (it will vent on its own)

Another major benefit is that your process can be more precise allowing for more consistent results. Obviously this isn't a perfect solution to make it hands off but it's something (also if it's a pi you could send the data it's reading to a seperate computer allowing you to easily make graphs or other representations of what's going on... Or you could host a small webserver that you can locally connect to that displays it all in a graph for you and all you would need is a webbrowser to access this).

36:55 It turning orange is probably caused by the same thing that makes it hazy blue in other conditions. It's the same effect as in the sky - during the day, the sky is blue, but as the sun sets it turns orange. Has to do with scattering. Higher frequencies, ie, blue are scattered more frequently, which gives it the blue haze. Under more other, direct lighting conditions however, the blue light gets scattered away, making the lack of blue light, orange, visible. You might be able to see this by pointing a flashlight at the aerogel. It might turn orange as well when looking at the flashlight through the aerogel.


Edit: You can actually see it at 39:15!

One interesting (but rather niche) application of aerogel is in thermonuclear warheads. The aerogel presumably helps generate the radiation pressure to compress the lithium deuteride "fusion fuel" in the secondary. How it actually works is still a very classified state secret just about everywhere though so this is purely speculation based on the publicly available material. For the classified parts, one would need to find a reliable enemy spy, and with the lockdowns everywhere due to the Chinese flu, the spies may not be doing as much spying as usual.

The yellow/orangish tint around the edge of your aerogel is likely due to the decreased pathlength for light to travel near the edges/corners of the sample, and thus different scattering of light. This can also be observed in colloidal silica in the 40-60nm size range, which gives those a nice opalescent color. It is also possible the silica gel network has a slightly different density in those regions, probably due to the way the sol-gel dried, once again causing optical properties to be a bit different

You very probably were seeing the "blue haze" in the supercritical CO2 phase— there's some super interesting optics going on here!

The blue haze is "Rayleigh scattering", which affects how light falls on the object, and therefore how it looks. Rayleigh scattering means that long wavelengths of light (aka red light) go through the material unaffected, but short wavelengths (blue light) are bounced away in a random direction. This happens when there are tiny, microscopic imperfections in how the material bends light. If those variations/imperfections are the right size, you get Rayleigh scattering.

Basically what this means is that when you're looking at the material and light is coming in from the side, the only light you see is the light that's been scattered (bounced away) toward your eye, which as we said before is blue. The red light just goes straight through and doesn't get directed toward your eye, so you don't see it. So when light is coming in from the side, the material looks blue.

But the opposite happens if the light is coming through the material from behind, toward your eye— the blue light doesn't make it to your eye, it gets bounced away in some random direction! So when the material is backlit it looks red, because as we said before, only red light makes it through unaffected.

You had a light behind your setup, so the light was traveling through the CO2 into your camera. So the Rayleigh scattering in the CO2 was bouncing away the blue light and only letting red light through to the camera, and making the whole chamber look red.

Now here's the interesting bit: This exact same process is what makes the sky blue and sunsets red! When you look at the sky during the day, it looks blue, because the sunlight is hitting the air from the side (there's nothing behind it, only the blackness of space). But when the sun is setting, the sunlight skims the surface of the Earth and goes through a ton of atmosphere before it hits your eye (as opposed to taking a shorter path straight down through it, like during the day), and the Rayleigh scattering bounces all the blue light away and leaves only the red. So sunsets are red.

Rayleigh scattering is also what gives smoke its color— when you're looking at smoke from the side, it looks blueish. But when it's blotting out the sun, it looks extremely red. Same thing as the sky/sunsets, just way stronger! You'll also notice that the shadow of a smoke cloud looks red, even if the smoke itself looks blue.

This might also be why your hexagon sample looked orange. Rayleigh scattering is also what gives the aerogel itself its hazy blueness (and why it looks "smoky"); and just like the smoke, it will cast an orange/red shadow or be orange/red if you look through it. So if the Rayleigh scattering is particularly strong (perhaps due to the particular size of the air voids in the silica matrix), then the sample might look more reddish in some circumstances, partly because it tints the background red when you look through it, and partly because it's casting a red shadow on itself.

Great video!  You might look at using something other than regular PTFE tape for SS to SS pipe threads.  There's a real chance you'll end up galling (cold welding the high points) and ruining the part.  My favorite is Loctite 567 thread sealant.  You can also find grey-colored PTFE tape with a nickel compound that does the job.  Definitely worth it if you are assembling $400 threaded SS windows and other high dollar parts.

I am compression tech that works on high pressure stainless, white tape is for liquids (at atmospheric pressure) yellow is for low pressure gas, and GRAY is for high pressure gas. It might be coded differently in Canada, as  I've never come across orange, although it looked like standard gas tape in the video. With gray tape you usually only give 3 wraps. Joints fail more from too thick a layer of tape than too little. The tape isn't a gasket, it's a lubricant to allow tapered pipe thread to seal. I would have assembled sight glasses with an o-ring face seal if it was available, as a face seal is more reliable when disassembly is frequent. I believe you used o-ring seals in previous experiments with supercritical CO2.

This aerogel material is real neat, I bet it has some pretty interesting applications. First question on my mind is if you can dope the wafer and make it into a semiconductor without negatively affecting the final result. It would probably be handy as a thermal device or maybe as a light sensitive device if you could, but my gut feeling is that the much dopant elements would be too heavy and affect the wafer's integrity. To do multiple ones at a time, you should be able to add spur pipes made of schedule 80 stainless pipe (2" schedule 80 is rated for a working load of 2500 psi) off the sides of the cross with male to female couplers. You'd need a long flat rest to load/support the gel and more methanol at first to cover it since it wouldn't be in the bottom of the cross, but everything else seems like it would be the same process. The only limiting factors would be how big of a water bath you could create/heat uniformly and reliably.

@NileRed if you're still wondering about the orange/yellow color, it's due to Rayleigh scattering. Owing to the average size of the air pockets as well as their spatial distribution relative to one another. Look up (man-made) "opalite", you'll see pretty much the same effect as you saw in your aerogel, and it's due to much the same (structural) properties (rather than strictly chemical, or the color of incident light).

Basically orange appears due to lack of blue, which ends up scattered (and at the same time lending the aerogel its color, much like the sky appears blue due to uncompensated scattered light).

An option for a mould for future attempts may be wax. Using a wax mould means you could have a target shape that you shape the wax over, then fill the wax mould with aerogel, then heat to remove the wax. You could get delicate shapes with clean edges and could make a reproducable shape, but you could also use other removable things like paper to make even cleaner edges and simply burn off the remainder. Perhaps for making something like a thermally insulated flask you could simply use the destination vessel as the mould, removing the need for any moulding process at all.

I was just thinking about your procedure with supercritical fluid extraction and had a few questions for you. Was there a reason why you didn't go supercritical sooner in your process? I was just thinking about how important thorough mixing is in liquid liquid extractions and I was thinking that heating up your reaction vessel to higher temperatures might allow for better mixing of your methanol and CO2 once the CO2 goes supercritical. My understanding of this extraction process was that the impressive properties of CO2 as a solvent appear when it goes supercritical, not just in its liquid phase. Like in the extraction of caffeine from coffee. The supercritical state allows for the CO2 to pass freely through the solid coffee bean taking the caffeine with it. Would it not be the same with methanol here?

You know for the methanol supply issue, can probably set up a medium sized ethanol still. There was a dope TEK with a milk tank, and a copper tubing as your cylinder. Weld, and braise. Test with water. Two option for heating elements. Electric for safety. Gas for accuracy. Essentially a larger fractional still. It looked pretty attainable.

The methanol comes out first and is customarily disposed of or sold by companies doing it. But you could take that and get it much drier. And you can calculate with decent assurity your total break down of alcohol output by calculating you total sugar to water ratio in your mash, as well as you yeast strain. Ideally you have absolutely no sugar left over in your mash if you do it correctly, making it much more accurate. Plus ethanol solvent, which can be a pain to get sometimes, and way more expensive than it needs to be.

The yellow may be due to some effects of the scattering and the type of lighting you have in the room. This is the same effect that gives it the usual blue color the same way as rayleigh scattering does for the sky. It reflects blue light around, but is a long wavelength pass filter giving the light that passes through it (especially from the lighted printer paper) a yellow or red color as the sun does at sunset.  In summary,  looking at it makes it appear blue but looking through it makes other things yellow/orange.

36:55 That's Rayleigh scattering. Supercritical phase is not uniform. Light passing from the camera side is scattered more the lower the wavelength, so it looks like there's a blue haze. When light is shining through the other side, blue light is scattered away from the camera and warmer colors pass through more easily. The reason it disappears later is probably because the deeper you push it into supercritical region and longer it stays there, droplets of different density mix together so well the density variations become too low and droplet size too small to scatter visible light.


I bet if you shine light through your product it will also appear yellow, not because the substance has a color itself but due to scattering.

One thing I found really interesting is the color transition between the orange color in the (still) liquid phase and how it went away when the CO2 went further into the supercritical phase. My best guess is that at this particular point the different absorbtion spectra of liquid and gaseous CO2 cause some weird effect, which would explain the color going away further into the supercritical state considering gaseous CO2 doesn't absorb any visible light. I couldn't find an absorbtion spectrum of liquid or supercritical CO2 though, so I'm very much unsure this is the cause. Maybe it's just some contamination seeing as your final product was also kind of yellow, but then I have even less of an idea what could cause
such a weird effect. Either way, I'd love to hear any ideas or ressources on why this happens (perhaps someone can find information on the liquid/supercritical transition and their respective spectra or make sense of some byproduct that could have been formed that has this property).

I have two random thoughts on this; 1- load a few standing up, like a toaster. You can do a solid partition, or use a thin wire, and 2- use a second valve on the bottom with a short pipe between. Initially, the upper valve would be open and filled as part of the chamber. When it came time to drain the methanol, the upper would be closed and the lower opened, and then closed again and repeated. It might prevent pressure drops.

Tyndall scattering causes reflected light to be bluish, but transmitted light is golden.  I believe that's why your aerogel looks yellow.  I've synthesized opal and seen the same, although it happens in natural opal, too, when it's translucent enough.  I've even seen it in transparent soap I made, which I was not expecting at all.

No Nile the Teflon tape isn't a sealant, it's a lubricant! The amount of force that tapered threads exert on the flanks is enough to weld them together. The Teflon tape acts as a lubricant to keep the threads from welding together since a liquid lubricant would just squish out. At 10k psi, your fluid doesn't care if there's some Teflon in the way of the leak path.
